Locality: 8.0 km E of Coos Bay; Blue Ridge Road
Public Note: NOTES: "Bird was vocalizing from a couple of snags on slope containing saplings of Douglas Fir and Red Alder trees..."                [This exceptionally long recording contains a series of "Wuk" Calls (following BNA) at 0:16-0:30 and "songs", described on p. 420 of Short [1982. Woodpeckers of the World. Delaware Mus. Nat. Hist. 4:1-676] as fast Wuk Series Calls, at 8:25, 9:10 (distant bird in background), and 20:06.  By contrast, series of calls at 8:07-8:26, 9:45-9:53, 10:01-10:05, 10:18-10:21, 10:59, 11:10-11:15, 11:22-11:25, 11:35-11:39, 11:45-11:48, 11:49-11:52, 15:18-15:20, and 15:51-15:53 instead represent the "Wok" Call of Short 1982 (also p. 420).  Tapping is scattered almost throughout recording, with the best examples at 10:35-10:48 and 14:02-14:37, and there is some wing rustling at 18:14-18:16 and 19:26-19:28 when bird made brief flights.  There appear to be "cryptic" stop-starts at 5:26 and 12:57.  Quality changed from 1 to 2, 1-2 (the songs at 8:25 and 20:06 are the only parts in this recording even approaching quality 1) - CAM - 6 May 2005]

Recordist: Allen, Arthur A; Kellogg, Peter Paul
Public Note: NOTES: DRUMS. CALLS OF YOUNG. BEST TOWARD END.                  [As far as I can determine the calls in the foreground were all given by the same individual, presumably a fledged juvenile based on the above note.  Most calls here are the grating churrs or buzzes typical of young birds, but there are also 37 examples of the fast "Wuk Series Call" (see p. 420 of Short, L. L. 1982. Woodpeckers of the World. Delaware Mus. Nat. Hist. 4:1-676), and many slower "Wuk" Series, all apparently given by the same bird.  In the background are additional "Wuk Series Calls", a Drum at 12:55, and "Wok" Calls, the latter at 7:29-7:33, 11:16-11:18, 11:20-11:21, and 12:16-12:20.  Quality changed from 1 to 1-2 (though approaching quality 1 later in recording) - CAM - 9 May 2005]

Recordist: Heinzmann, George M; Agey, H. Norton
Public Note: NOTES: MIXED HARDWOODS WITH INTERSPERSING POPLAR-ASH SLOUGHS. VOCALIZATION IS FLICKER-LIKE BUT NOT FLICKER. SEE CORRESPONDENCE 19APR69. ADDITIONAL MATERIAL FROM 03MAR68 IS ALSO INCLUDED.  Sex: 1 UNKNOWN  [Well, I'm not sure what to say here.  As far as I can determine, there are only four original sound clips here.  The recordings at 0:04-0:32 and 0:49-0:57 are certainly flicker-like, especially the contiuous series at 0:04-0:21 and 0:26-0:32, but I am less certain about the latter part of the first series (0:21-0:23), which appears to have been recopied twice at 0:41-0:48.  A similar vocalization is included at 0:49-0:57 (recopied at 0:59-1:06).  Given the very different quality of these sounds relative to those in LNS #6784, combined with the close similarity of the calls to those of Colatpes auratus, leads me to doubt that any of these sounds were given by C. principalis.  The recordings from 3 March 1968 (2:45-3:07) represent the calls of Buteo lineatus.  Quality unchanged (2;3 - the signal is not bad for the first part, but terrible for the rest, most of which seems to represent copies of various recordings) - CAM - 22 April 2005]

AgeSex: Juvenile Unknown Sex (3); Adult Unknown Sex (1)
Behavior: beg; call; establish parent young contact
Public Note: Vocalizations given by half-grown juveniles in nest hole. Three feedings occur during taping. Squawk-like raspings and variations of flicker-like call.    General climate: Dry.  Cover density: Medium.    BNA: The "Wuk" Call is heard ("kuk-kuk, kuk-kuk" etc) at the beginning followed by juvenile begging calls. In the last segment, possibly "Wok Call" is heard (6-8 high-pitched cuks with a terminal cuk of lower pitch).  (CZ  08/03/2004)  Most of the sounds here are the begging calls of the nestlings, but it is unclear to me whether these represent the soft churr notes of small young, the buzzing of older young, or something in the middle.  There are also two "songs" by the adults (0:155, 0:225), described on p. 420 of Short [1982. Woodpeckers of the World. Delaware Mus. Nat. Hist. 4:1-676] as fast Wuk Series Calls, and scattered series of what appear to be "Wuk" Calls (1:57-1:58, 2:17-2:24, 2:26-2:29, 2:32-2:35, 2:41-2:44) that could have been given by either an adult or a nestling (though more likely an adult).   (CAM 6 May 2005)
